subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... True, but it still means they can t spell these words by ear , but *must* refer to their knowledge of TO. ... The basic rule is quite simple: the default
messageBody:
On 2007-12-04 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>>> Read already put quite a burden on non-rhotic speakers
>>> by demanding of them that they write Roe everywhere
>>> where rhotic speakers pronounce /r/. In that light it
>>> is perhaps not unreasonable to expect that speakers who
>>> have merged all of LOT-(CLOTH)-THOUGHT-FATHER to write
>>> their /A/ mostly with Ox but sometimes with At, but
>>> relieve them of having to learn *three* different
>>> 'orthographic sets' with Ox, Awe or Ah for one single
>>> phoneme, by postulating that Ox be written wherever non-
>>> merging speakers have /Q/ or /O/ and Ah wherever non-
>>> merging speakers have /A/ or /{/.
>
> I have two questions:
> 1) How heavy a burden is it for non-rhotic speakers to
> include /r/ is their QS writing? After all, they
> already do so when writing in TO, and it is quite
> difficult to foresee a future in which TO has been
> forgotten.

True, but it still means they can't spell these words 'by
ear', but *must* refer to their knowledge of TO.

> 2) As someone who merges LOT, CLOTH, THOUGHT, and PALM,
> I'm willing to give this a try... except, I haven't any
> idea how to get started. Without a QS dictionary in
> which to look up every word in these sets, I have no
> way to answer the question, How would a non-merging
> speaker pronounce this word?

The basic rule is quite simple: the default spelling for
your /A/ is Ox, but spell it with At where the TO spelling
is _a_ without a following _u_ or _w_. The problematic set
is those words where TO has _al_, but you should mostly be
safe using Ox in these cases: even _palm_ has a minority
pronunciation /pQlm/!

I am working on a dictionary, based on a perl script which
heuristically doctors the transcriptions of the CMU
phonetic dictionary. There will be room for errors and inde-
terminacies which will have to be checked against the LPD
by hand, but I could release an alpha version with
uncorrected errors.

I have decided to keep Ah-Roe for START and Awe-Roe for NORTH-
FORCE, since these are in fact easier to write than At-Roe
and Ox-Roe.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
